awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Tree-based artificial intelligence (AI) models for financial fraud detection
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of fraud detection software for use in financial services, such as banks and credit card companies.  Fraud detection is a costly problem with annual losses of billions of dollars to banks, merchants, and customers. Another cost is reputational, as cardholders reduce patronage to merchants after transaction declines. This team seeks to provide fraud detection artificial intelligence (AI) software for commercial banks with an accuracy that exceeds industry standards, potentially saving banks millions of dollars. The technology is based on a fundamental innovation in learning decision trees and forests which makes it possible to improve the state of the art in fraud detection along several fronts: a superior predictive accuracy and fewer false positives; a faster prediction time, necessary for processing many transactions per second; and models that are explainable and trustworthy.

This I-Corps project is based fraud detection that can be framed as a binary classification problem, where a transaction is classified as legitimate or fraudulent. Current practical fraud detection systems often use decision trees and forests trained on large datasets of past transactions. However, learning a tree from data requires solving a very difficult mathematical optimization problem. Until recently, this was approximated using heuristic algorithms dating from the 1980s which provide suboptimal models. The proposed algorithm, based on modern optimization principles, seeks to find much better solutions while scaling to large datasets. The technology may result in more accurate models, but also in shallower trees, which are easier to explain and audit and which can compute predictions faster. The technology can also learn more general types of tree-based models, which may lead to further improvements in performance in applications such as credit scoring, and in the legal, government and public health sectors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The present NSF I-Corps award originates from our desire to commercialize machine learning research carried out at the University of California, Merced based on advanced tree-based predictive models. The fundamental improvement arises from a new algorithm, Tree Alternating Optimization (TAO), based on modern optimization techniques, which can learn trees and forests that have a considerably lower prediction error and false-positive rate than the traditional algorithms, yet the models learned can remain interpretable to humans and thus easier to audit, and are small enough for use in real-time transaction processing. The team chose to focus on a financial application, fraud detection and credit scoring software for banks and credit card companies. This is an important problem, with annual losses of billions of dollars to banks, merchants, and customers, where both predictive power and explainability of the model is critical.

Our goal was to determine the viability of our proposed innovation. To this end, during the I-Corps training, our team completed a customer discovery process consisting of 100 interviews (mostly remote) with a range of stakeholders. Their roles included, among others, data science/machine learning engineers, corporate security experts and department heads or directors. Their companies were either financial companies (including large commercial banks, small/mid-sized financial organizations, credit reporting agencies and credit card companies), or machine learning companies (including those that specialize in software for fraud detection or credit scoring, as well as general AI companies that provide ML solutions for various industries). One general problem we found is that companies working in this area are very reluctant, out of security concerns, to provide information about how they carry out fraud detection or credit scoring. This is unlike other industries, where potential customers are happy to describe their current solution and what needs improving. Even harder was to get a financial institution to provide us with some test data on which to train our models and demonstrate their performance. For example, credit card transaction data, even legacy data, is highly private and a critical asset, and it cannot leave the bank under any circumstance. Our team pivoted several times as it learnt information, sometimes contradictory, from different customers. Once thing that become evident over multiple interviews is that interpretability of the models is critical, particularly for credit scoring.

Our conclusion is that, while companies do use AI for fraud detection and credit scoring, many appear to be using old-fashioned models, often rule-based systems, whose predictive performance could be significantly improved while maintaining model explainability. The team's tree-based algorithms can fill that need. Thus, the team has created a startup and is working on developing 1) a plug-and-play prototype that can be directly integrated into an existing machine learning pipeline for fraud detection or credit scoring; and 2) a suite of case studies demonstrating the superiority of the technology in predictive power, false positive rate and model interpretability. The team will explore commercialization opportunities, such as licensing, either with financial companies directly or with companies providing fraud detection solutions.
